importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article reflects the ongoing and recent impact of tropical storms on Mexico, highlighting a current emergency situation.
The date marks when Tropical Storm Raymond was being monitored for landfall, indicating active weather threats in the region.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame reflects the immediate aftermath of flooding and storm impacts, with emergency responses and recovery efforts underway.

keyTakeAways: At least 37 people have died in Mexico due to flooding caused by heavy rainfall from tropical storms.
The worst-affected regions include Veracruz, Hidalgo, Queretaro, Puebla, and San Luis Potosi.
Hidalgo reported 22 deaths, 1,000 homes damaged, and 90 communities inaccessible; Puebla reported 9 deaths and affected 80,000 people.
Veracruz reported five deaths, including a police officer, and 5,000 homes damaged; navy evacuated nearly 900 people.
A child died in Queretaro after being caught in a landslide.
Over 320,000 people experienced power outages, and nearly 1,000 km of roads were damaged.
The Mexican Navy deployed 3,300 personnel, 18 vessels, 6 helicopters, 3 water purification plants, 3 aircraft, 3 mobile kitchens, and 4,000 food baskets.
More than 8,700 military personnel were deployed to assist in evacuation, monitoring, and cleanup.
The Sierra Madre Oriental mountain range was a primary disaster area due to its topography and location.
Tropical Storm Raymond is expected to landfall in southern Baja California over the weekend and weaken to a tropical depression by Sunday.
Raymond joins Tropical Storm Priscilla and post-Tropical Cyclone Octave as part of a week of intense rainfall events off western Mexico.
The Pacific Ocean cooling pattern known as La Nina has returned and is linked to increased rainfall and extreme weather globally.
Mexico has experienced unusually heavy rains throughout 2025, with a rainfall record set in Mexico City.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A tropical storm forming off the Pacific coast of Mexico, projected to make landfall in southern Baja California.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is directly responsible for heavy rainfall that caused flooding and landslides in central and southeastern Mexico, including in Puebla, Veracruz, and San Luis Potosi.

namedEntities.name: Tropical Storm Priscilla

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It contributed to the pattern of heavy rainfall across western Mexico, adding to the overall disaster impact and climate stress.

namedEntities.name: Post-Tropical Cyclone Octave
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A former tropical cyclone that brought heavy rains to parts of Mexico, contributing to flooding and damage.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It preceded Raymond and Priscilla, contributing to a sequence of extreme weather events that increased the risk of disaster across multiple states.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mexico is facing a severe humanitarian crisis after at least 37 people died in flooding and landslides caused by heavy rainfall from tropical storms, including Raymond, Priscilla, and Octave. The worst-hit states are Hidalgo, Puebla, Veracruz, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosí, with Hidalgo reporting 22 fatalities and over 1,000 homes damaged, while Puebla affected more than 80,000 people. The Sierra Madre Oriental mountain range was particularly vulnerable due to its topography. The Mexican government responded with over 8,700 military personnel and extensive naval deployments, including 3,300 personnel and emergency supplies. Climate factors, such as the return of La Nina, are believed to have contributed to the extreme rainfall, which has persisted throughout 2025. Tropical Storm Raymond is expected to landfall in southern Baja California and weaken by Sunday. Authorities are focused on restoring power, reopening roads, and providing shelter to displaced populations.
title: At least 37 people killed in flooding caused by tropical storms in Mexico
